Thank you for your patience. ::: :::: Pipes (`|`) allow the output of one command (`stdout`) to be used as the input (`stdin`) to another, enabling the chaining of commands to perform complex tasks with the output of one serving as the input for the next. We'll use the @sec-grep command as an example to illustrate `stdin`. Imagine you want to find the word "dress" in a file named `roxanne` in the `data/` folder. Instead of directly providing the file as an argument to @sec-grep, you can use @sec-cat to read the file and then pipe (`|`) its output into @sec-grep, utilizing `stdin` to receive the file content. ::: {.cell} ```{.bash .cell-code} cat data/roxanne | grep dress ## You don't have to wear that dress tonight ``` ::: In this command: 1. `cat data/roxanne` reads the content of `roxanne` and *sends* it to `stdout` 2. The pipe `|` *redirects* the `stdout` from @sec-cat to the `stdin` of @sec-grep. 3. `grep dress` *receives* the file's content through `stdin`, searches for the word "dress", and *prints* lines containing it to `stdout`. Here, @sec-grep's input comes from `stdin` (provided by the pipe) instead of directly reading from a file. ::: {.cell} ```{.bash .cell-code} ls /bin | head -n5 ## [ ## bash ## cat ## chmod ## cp ``` ::: :::: {.callout-note collapse='false' appearance='default' icon=false} ## [See a typo, error, or something missing?]{style='font-weight: bold; font-size: 0.95em;'} ::: {style='font-size: 0.90em; color: #282b2d;'} Please open an issue on [GitHub.](https://github.com/mjfrigaard/fm-unix/issues/new) ::: ::::
